results.title: Join the navy and see the world they say
results.creator_credit: Ron Baguley, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Inspired by his childhood hero, ‘Uncle Jack’, Ron Baguley enlisted in the Navy at the ripe age of 16. “Join the Navy and see the world they say!” In 1952, Ron was plucked from his job as a carpenter and thrown into a life at sea, serving initially in the Korean Conflict. Ron tracks his incredibly journey from a young recruit to a senior warrant officer.
results.title_for_label: Join the navy and see the world they say
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ron Baguley, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: An interview with Cyril Sayles
results.brief_description: At the age of 16, Cyril Sayles, not wanting to continue his manual labour in the mines, decided to join the army. Having lied about his age, he had a special made uniform and was off to fight the Germans in World War II. Cyril humorously shares his story of strength and courage, through his battle and imprisonment during the war.

results.title: A Boy called "Rabbit"
results.creator_credit: Ken Cumming, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ken Cumming’s dearest memory of the time he served in Vietnam was a young boy by the name of “Rabbit”. While “Rabbit” couldn’t speak English, he was popular with the Australian soldiers for his fast running and bravery.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Cumming, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Pharmaceutical girl
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Parker, David Atkinson and Dik Jarman
results.brief_description: ‘Pharmaceutical girl’ is not strictly a claymation. The creator Dik Jarman with Nick Pledge set about experimenting with an alternate type of puppet. Pledge created an internal armitage complete with moving joints and rising chest cavity, whilst Jarman designed and sculpted the puppet using an alternate latex type of skin to form the flesh of the puppet. A surreal animation that takes us on the journey of Sukei and her addiction. Dealt mostly with symbolism, the pricks of the rose replace the syringe. The set (of which Jarman won an award for) is both functional for the purpose of shooting scenes with moveable walls etc, but also represents Sukei’s mind as the greater part of the set makes up the internals of a clock. As she begins to hallucinate the clock-like set begins to grind to a halt and then into reverse, Sukei’s dream takes over. What initially begins as peaceful escape quickly turns into a nightmare. (The soundtrack is by Edwina Blush and Thierry Cotco Lovett).

results.title: The Ladies' man; Lord Byron lived here; The Lift
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Hancock’s half hour”.
Three episodes from the British television comedy series “Hancock” starring Tony Hancock. 1. The Ladies man: Hancock decides to take things into his own hands and improve his success rate with the opposite sex. 2. Lord Byron lives here: The discovery of scribblings by the great poet Byron leads Hancock to open his house as a stately home, exploit the American tourists and make a fortune at the same time. The Lift: What a captive audience has top put up with when Hancock tips the balance of one too many in the lift and the lift won’t budge.

results.title: The Land before time: the big freeze
results.brief_description: This animated children’s film is the seventh sequel to Don Bluth’s “The Land before time” (1988) and continues the adventures of Littlefoot, a young and impetuous apatosaurus. In this instalment Littlefoot lives contentedly with his elderly grandparents in Great Valley, but when they experience a snowstorm for the first time, excitement turns to concern upon realising that significant climate change odes badly for the dinosaur community. Ducky, an anatosaurus, experiences sibling rivalry, resentful of her adopted brother, Spike, a stegosaurus who has to decide whether to join his own migrating tribe or stay with his adoptive family. When several family members become stranded and their lives are imperilled, Ducky learns the value of respecting her elders, particularly Mr Thicknose, a dinosaur with whom he falls into constant conflict. Although the plot is trite, and the dialogue cloying, this animated children’s movie still entertains as it imagines the world inhabited by dinosaurs. Features frequent musical interludes and the voices of Jeff Bennett, Rob Paulsen, Aria Noelle Curzon, Thomas Dekker, Robert Guillaume, Susan Krebs and Kenneth Mars.
